awd_abstract_narration:
The use of light to measure and manipulate mechanical objects has recently seen dramatic advances in the field of quantum optomechanics.  It is now possible to cool a macroscopic mechanical resonator to near absolute zero using radiation pressure inside an optical cavity.  Conversely, by reflecting a laser field off a low-loss mechanical resonator, it is possible to “squeeze” its statistical fluctuations beyond classical limits, providing a resource for quantum-enhanced interferometric measurements. This project will combine both techniques to develop next-generation optomechanical inertial sensors, in which light is used to probe the displacement of a mechanical resonator in response to accelerating reference frame.  In addition to precision applications such as space-based gravimetry and inertial navigation, the project will open the door to fundamental experiments such as accelerometry below the standard quantum limit and calibration of acceleration to fundamental constants. The long-term vision is a new class of field-deployable, miniaturized quantum technology.

Specific goals of the project are (1) demonstrate the first chip-scale optomechanical accelerometer with nano-g sensitivity (enabling precision applications such as inertial navigation and gravimetry in a compact form factor), (2) demonstrate a squeezing-enhanced optomechanical accelerometer by realizing ponderomotive light squeezing in an acoustic frequency cavity optomechanical system; (3) use radiation pressure shot noise to calibrate an optomechanical accelerometer to fundamental constants; and (4) use radiation pressure to stabilize an optomechanical accelerometer, by harnessing high fidelity coherent and measurement-based feedback cooling techniques. To accomplish these goals, the researchers will refine two advanced sensor designs representing complementary expertise of the PI and co-PI:  (1) a centimeter-scale high stress silicon nitride membrane integrated in a Fabry-Perot cavity and (2) a bulk fused-silica optomechanical resonator integrated with a fiber cavity.  As an enabling tool, the PI/CoPI will also develop a compact laser source capable of shot-noise-limited operation at acoustic frequencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Optomechanical accelerometers hold promise as a first generation quantum technology, combining shot-noise-limited interferometric readout and chip-scale form factor.  In NSF project "Quantum-enhanced Optomechanical Accelerometers" include (QOMA), we aimed to accelerate this technology by investigating the use of radiation pressure and nonclassical light to improve the sensitivity of an optomechancial accelerometer beyond the traditional shot noise limit.  A key enabling tool was to be the use of high-Q micromechancial resonators (silicon nitride nanomembranes and fused silica cantilevers) as acceleration test masses, and optical cavities for their readout.

Several key intended outcomes were achieved, several (unintended) discoveries were made long the way, and a new application emerged.

Key intended outcomes:

1.  We realized the first chip-scale optomechanical accelerometer with sub-micro-g resolution.  Specifically, we engineered an accelerometer based on a pair of vertically integrated silicon nitride nanomembranes forming an optical cavity, and demonstrated a thermal noise limited acceleration resolution of 500 ng.  The device platform is simple and scalable.

2.  We showed that radiation pressure could be used to significantly improve the resolution of an optomechanical accelerometer.  Specifically, radiation pressure damping was used to cool our membrane-based accelerometer to an effective temperature of 1 mK, reducing the thermal acceleration noise to an effective value of 50 ng.

3.  In collaborative and co-funded work (NSF 2040575), we realized the first squeezing-enhanced optomechanical sensor array.  Specifically, we built a 2-element array of membrane-based optomechanical accerometers, probed the array with a distributed squeezed light source, and demonstrated a 40% increase in sensitivity to a joint force.

Discoveries:

4. In co-funded work (NSF 2040575), we discovered a new class of ultra-high-Q torsion resonators based on silicon nitride nanoribbons.  We showed that these nanoresonators could be used to engineer chip-scale torsion pendula sensitive to gravity at the micro-g level, using frequency as a measurand. 

5. In learning to monitor the torsion nanoresonators in (4), we realized the first angular displacement measurement with a imprecision below that at the Standard Quantum Limit.  We accomplished this task with an optical lever---a form of non-interferometric displacement measurent---signaling the possibility of a new field of imaging-based quantum optomechanics.

6. We discovered a new form of nonlinear radiation pressure noise (thermal intermodulation backaction) that fundamentally limits the observation of radiation pressure quantum noise in room temperature optomechanical systems.

New application:

7.  In parallel with QOMA, the field of optomechanics became interested in using optomechanical sensors to search for dark matter.  We had a unique opportunity to contribute to this program in its early phases, and proposed the use of cryogenic arrays of optomechanical accelerometers as detectors for ultralight (wave-like) dark matter.  Our membrane-based optomechanical accelerometers are well-suited for this task, and experimental efforts are underway, supported independently by NSF (2209473).
